stream_context.summary: Kaze grey-boxes the new “Snowman Cave” inside the castle, tunes an elevator effect on real N64 hardware, and chats about upcoming demos, optimisations, and imminent parenthood.

development_findings.summary: Outlined four major rooms for Snowman Cave: (1) uphill slide while snowmen attack, (2) platforms over a bottomless void, (3) cliff-climbing section, (4) downhill slide leading to a treasure room with coins and a star.
development_findings.quote: “One room I want is kind of like a slide that you climb up… another one is platforms over a void… there needs to be a slide going down.”

development_findings.summary: Wants only snowman enemies in this area to keep a strong theme.
Plans a new shadow system where Mario’s shadow is a separate object that independently finds the floor, fixing jump-on-object issues.
development_findings.quote: “My idea for the shadows is that it’s actually going to be a whole separate object, separate from Mario.”

development_findings.summary: Elevator chosen over teleport for ease; auto-returns when stuck; shake effect tweaked (reduced magnitude, removed FOV shake) to feel less like a bug.
development_findings.quote: “Why did you make the elevator actually move instead of teleporting the player? – Why not? It’s just easier.”

development_findings.summary: Pits in the castle use ‘oily water’: player is lifted back up and loses health instead of dying, with a custom sound planned.
development_findings.quote: “Oily water has the property that… you just kind of get lifted back up and you lose some health.”

development_findings.summary: Anti-aliasing feature demonstrated on real console; still imperfect but aims for negligible performance hit; N-PRIM pipeline gives only ~1 FPS gain.
Committed to staying within original N64 limits (≤64 MB ROM, performance budgets); voice lines considered too costly in ROM space.
development_findings.quote: “If I don’t stay within the original limitations, am I not kind of cheating?”

development_findings.summary: Course 1 public demo planned soon after 1 August; will ship with Google form to gather detailed feedback on physics and camera.
development_findings.quote: “I’m going to have a Google document where people can answer all kinds of questions… so I can make minuscule adjustments.”

development_findings.summary: After RTYI, intends to open-source all engine optimisations so they can be ported back to vanilla SM64.
development_findings.quote: “After ESO is done I’ll likely start an open source project to do that.”

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels mentally foggy, likely from daily swimming with Zeina.
context_findings.quote: “We went swimming so much this week… maybe that’s why I’m feeling so tired today.”

context_findings.summary: His first child (a girl named Raina) is due in five days; streams may pause for hospital stay.
context_findings.quote: “In five days my daughter is likely going to be born… I might not be able to stream next week.”

context_findings.summary: Nintendo has taken down about 70 of his videos, reinforcing legal caution.
context_findings.quote: “They took down 70 of my videos… they fucking hate me.”

context_findings.summary: Hiring a video editor at ~$16 per finished minute to scale YouTube output; sees path to a million subscribers.
Reflects on isolation period of four years without speaking to anyone, valuing boredom and simple pleasures.
context_findings.quote: “Sometimes there’s things you feel like happened but they didn’t because you actually just dreamed them.”

biobak.summary: Reviews every finished model from Kaze and ‘makes it look a lot better’.
biobak.quote: “Whenever I’m done with a model, he looks over it again and makes it look a lot better.”

badub.summary: Composes the game’s music; present during stream chat.

zeina.summary: Creates most animations and concept art for RTYI.
zeina.quote: “Yeah, animations are the biggest one she’s doing.”

zeina.summary: Pregnancy influences schedule; her brother accidentally cut the lawn-mower cable during stream.

key_stories.title: Taming the Elevator Shake
key_stories.summary: Kaze replaced a teleport with a physical elevator in the castle. Initial camera and FOV shakes looked buggy, so he iteratively reduced magnitude and removed FOV wobble while watching console output.
key_stories.challenge: Elevator motion felt visually jarring and caused player confusion.
key_stories.process: Tweaked ‘magnitude’, ‘detail’, and removed FOV shake in code; tested repeatedly on hardware.
key_stories.outcome: Settled on subtle positional shake only; plans custom sound effect.
key_stories.key_quote: “The FOV shake kind of makes this look like a bugged camera, doesn’t it?”

key_stories.title: Reinventing Shadows
key_stories.summary: Existing shadow code fails when Mario stands on moving objects. Kaze designed a fix to detach the shadow into its own actor that independently finds ground.
key_stories.challenge: Shadows slid off elevators and moving platforms.
key_stories.process: Conceptual redesign during stream; will implement separate shadow object.
key_stories.outcome: Expected to give correct contact and separate collision layers.
key_stories.key_quote: “It will be a separate object that finds the floor properly… that way it will be all fine.”

key_stories.title: Designing the Snowman Cave
key_stories.summary: Live brainstorming produced a four-part layout: uphill slide with attacking snowmen, void platforming, cliff climb, and a downhill slide into a treasure room.
key_stories.challenge: Needed engaging variety while using only snowman enemies.
key_stories.process: Sketched ideas in Blender, discussed aesthetics (ice pillars, rocks, reflective surfaces), and placed grey-box geometry.
key_stories.outcome: Core platforming blueprint finished; visual pass to come.
key_stories.key_quote: “We gotta think about rooms for the snowman cave… can we do more than that?”
